message.content:
In Markdown, code highlighting is typically achieved using fenced code blocks with a specific syntax highlighting language specified after the opening fences. Here are some common code types used for syntax highlighting in Markdown: ### Common Code Types for Syntax Highlighting - **JavaScript**: Used for JavaScript code snippets. ```javascript console.log("Hello, World!"); ``` - **Python**: Used for Python code snippets. ```python print("Hello, World!") ``` - **HTML**: Used for HTML code snippets. ```html

Hello, World!

``` - **CSS**: Used for CSS code snippets. ```css body { background-color: lightblue; } ``` - **Java**: Used for Java code snippets. ```java public class HelloWorld { public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println("Hello, World!"); } } ``` - **C++**: Used for C++ code snippets. ```cpp #include using namespace std; int main() { cout << "Hello, World!" << endl; return 0; } ``` - **Ruby**: Used for Ruby code snippets. ```ruby puts "Hello, World!" ``` - **PHP**: Used for PHP code snippets. ```php ``` - **Bash**: Used for shell script snippets. ```bash echo "Hello, World!" ``` - **SQL**: Used for SQL query snippets. ```sql SELECT * FROM users; ``` These are just a few examples. Most Markdown renderers support a wide range of languages for syntax highlighting. The exact list of supported languages can vary depending on the Markdown parser or renderer being used. @EOF@ [Markdown, codeHighlighting, JavaScript, Python, HTML, CSS, Java, C++, Ruby, PHP, Bash, SQL, syntaxLanguages, codeSnippets]
